responses: The University of the Immaculate Conception (UIC) is a Catholic, Filipino, RVM institution committed to transformative Ignacian Marian education.
UIC envisions its graduates to be Ignacian Marian leaders, responsible global citizens with profound faith in God, inspired by humble service, and committed to excellence.
The University adheres to the RVM Philosophy of Education, which centers on God, Jesus Christ, and Mary, with inspiration from Mother Ignacia del Espiritu Santo.

The school seal includes 'AM' for 'Ave Maria,' stars representing Mary's prerogatives, rays of light from God, a Sampaguita symbolizing purity, and the Latin inscription 'Initium sapientiae timor Domini'.
The school motto is 'Initium Sapientiae Timor Domini,' which means 'The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom'.
The vision of UIC is to be a globally recognized Catholic university that nurtures faith, builds a passion for excellence, and develops lifelong learners with compassion for service.

The mission includes providing excellent education, inculcating service values, engaging in research, upholding the dignity of the poor, promoting Filipino culture, and administering the university according to Catholic doctrine.
UIC’s core values are Faith, Excellence, and Service.

The Institutional Learning Outcomes (ILOs) include being a Critical Thinker, Information Competent, Creative, Effective Communicator, Faithful Collaborator, Socially and Ethically Responsible, and a Life-Long Learner.
The BS Accountancy program aims to produce graduates with professional accounting competence, who adapt to changes in standards, and engage in activities reflecting faith, service, and excellence.

patterns: Bachelor of Science in Accounting Information System
responses: The BS Accounting Information System program aims to produce graduates with professional accounting competence, who can adapt to changes and engage in activities reflecting faith, service, and excellence.

patterns: Bachelor of Science in Business Administration - Financial Management
responses: The BSBA in Financial Management program aims to produce graduates who are ethical, creative, and competent in the field of financial management.

patterns: BSBA major in Human Resource Management
responses: The BSBA in Human Resource Management program aims to produce graduates who are ethical, creative, and competent in the field of human resource management.
The BSBA in Marketing Management program aims to produce graduates who are ethical, creative, and competent in the field of marketing management.

patterns: Bachelor of Science in Real Estate Management
responses: The BS in Real Estate Management program aims to produce graduates who are ethical, creative, and competent in the field of real estate management.
The Bachelor of Elementary Education program produces graduates proficient in teaching, with knowledge of diverse cultures and values.
The Bachelor of Special Needs Education program focuses on creating respectful and inclusive learning experiences for students with additional needs.
The Bachelor of Early Childhood Education program aims to produce graduates who are responsive to the needs of young children, with Christian values.
The Bachelor of Physical Education program aims to produce graduates with skillful performance in physical activities, and who can create relevant learning programs.
The BSED major in Mathematics program aims to produce graduates with competence in mathematical concepts and procedures.
The BSED major in Science program aims to produce graduates with a deep understanding of scientific concepts.
The BSED major in English program aims to produce graduates with broad knowledge of the English language and its use.
The BSED major in Filipino program aims to produce graduates with knowledge in teaching Filipino language and literature, as well as culture.
The BS Architecture program aims to produce graduates who can apply research methods to address architectural problems.

patterns: Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering
responses: The BS Civil Engineering program aims to produce graduates who can apply mathematics and science to solve civil engineering problems.

patterns: Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering
responses: The BS Computer Engineering program aims to produce graduates who can apply math and science to solve computer engineering problems.
The BS Electronics Engineering program aims to produce graduates who can apply math and science to solve electronics engineering problems.
The AB English Language Studies program aims to produce graduates with a comprehensive view of the English language.
The BA Philosophy program aims to produce graduates who can think critically and analyze theories.
The BA Psychology program aims to produce graduates who can analyze psychological theories and apply research methods.
The BA Communication program aims to produce graduates who can communicate in different formats and platforms.
The BS Computer Science program aims to produce graduates who can design complex software and develop new algorithms.
The BS Information Technology program aims to produce graduates who can configure IT infrastructure and provide technical expertise.
The BS Information Systems program aims to produce graduates who can implement information systems and provide technical expertise.
The Bachelor in Medical Laboratory Science program aims to produce graduates with competence in clinical laboratory tests and health information.
The BM Music Education program aims to produce graduates who can apply knowledge of music education to solve problems and design productions.
The BS Nutrition and Dietetics program aims to produce graduates who can assess nutritional needs and manage nutrition programs.

intents.tag: Hotel, Restaurant and Institution Management Program
patterns: BS Hotel, Restaurant and Institution Management
responses: The BS Hotel, Restaurant and Institution Management program aims to produce graduates with competence in hospitality management.
The BS Tourism Management program aims to produce graduates with competence in tourism management and tour guiding.
The BS Nursing program aims to produce graduates who can apply knowledge of health sciences and provide holistic care.
The BS Chemistry program aims to produce graduates who can solve chemistry problems and engage in professional development.
The BS Pharmacy program aims to produce graduates who can practice as professional pharmacists and provide pharmaceutical care.
The Tertiary Department aims to produce graduates who are Integrated, God-centered, Nationalistic, Innovative, Transformative, and Service-oriented (IGNITES).
Students are expected to demonstrate good manners and right conduct in the office, stairway, and canteen.
UIC has an open admission policy but reserves the right to refuse admission.
New students must submit placement exam results, high school report card, PSA birth certificate, and other documents.
Returnees must submit previous grades and a clearance if suspended/excluded.
Transferees must submit a transcript of records, honorable dismissal, and PSA birth certificate.
Shiftees must submit a parent's consent to shift.
International students can inquire through the registrar's office and must submit notarized documents.
International students need to submit a passport, visa, ACR (if applicable), affidavit of support, and police clearance.
The application for a student visa requires a letter request, medical certificate, and other documents.
Student visa extension requires a Certificate of Re-admission or enrollment and transcript.
Students with three failures or not meeting program standards may not be readmitted, but may be allowed to shift to another program under certain conditions.
Changing or dropping courses requires approval from the Program Dean and completion of a form.
UIC uses an Outcomes-Based Education framework, placing the Ignacian Marian learner at the heart of the curriculum.
Students with excessive unexcused absences will be referred to the Guidance Office.
Absences due to illness, death of a family member, or natural calamities may be excused.
Examination schedules are announced in advance; cheating is prohibited, and special examinations may be given for valid reasons.
Cheating includes looking at others' papers, talking, using unauthorized materials, and using electronic gadgets.
Special examinations can be given to students who missed exams due to illness, death, or school representation.
Students with at least 90% average and no misbehavior may be exempted from final exams.
UIC uses a percentage-based grading system, with NA for Not Attending, DRP for Dropped, and PAS/F for Passed/Failed.
Students who excel academically may receive First, Second, or Third Honors.
Graduation awards include Summa Cum Laude, Magna Cum Laude, and Cum Laude, with specific GPA and requirements.
The Mother Ignacia award is given to students with exemplary conduct, leadership, and loyalty.
The Most Active Student Award is given to students who excel in leadership and school participation.
Non-academic awards include the Culture and Arts Award, Athlete Award, and Service Award.
The TCI Award is given to graduating staff who have shown dedication to the campus press.
The Most Active Organization award recognizes clubs that have contributed to the school.
Program awards are given to students who excel in specific areas.
Students must complete academic and internship requirements to be eligible for graduation.
Students with lacking requirements can appeal to join the graduation ceremony.
UIC offers scholarships for high school honors students and those who achieve high scores on the scholarship exam.
Students must wear the prescribed uniform. A letter of explanation is required for not wearing the proper uniform.
Students must wear and display their ID cards at all times within the school premises.
Students should respect authority, maintain order, and observe the CLAYGO policy.
Single-use plastics are prohibited within the campus.
Classes begin and end with prayer. The study hall is for studying, and silence must be observed.
Students must use school facilities with care and report any deficiencies.
All notices, posters, and announcements must be approved before posting.
Concerns should be brought to the attention of the Program Dean or Unit Head.
Off-campus activities must be approved by OSAD, with required documents including parent's consent.
Students should observe silence during prayer time.
Disciplinary actions include warnings, suspensions, exclusion, and expulsion.
UIC conducts random drug testing to maintain a safe environment while respecting student rights.
UIC follows due process in disciplinary cases, based on CHED guidelines and the Manual of Regulations.

patterns: Office of Student Affairs and Discipline
responses: The Office of Student Affairs and Discipline (OSAD) handles disciplinary cases.
Student organizations must submit their Constitution and By-Laws and membership lists to OSAD.
Student organizations must submit performance, financial, and activity reports to OSAD.
The Supreme Student Government (SSG) is the highest student governing body and voice.
UIC supports student publications, including the official student publication, TCI.
TCI aims to unite the academic community, develop values, and promote responsible journalism.
UIC Learning Resources include libraries, laboratories, and internet access.
The Father Selga Campus has laboratories for computer hardware, nutrition, pharmaceutical mini-manufacturing, science, and speech.
The Bonifacio Campus has laboratories for architecture, radio, soil mechanics, and speech.
Other facilities include chapels, a gymnasium, ITDIF, and mini-auditorium.
UIC NET provides internet services to the school and the community.
The Center for Continuing Studies and Professional Development (CCSPD) provides programs for professional competence.
The M. Ignacia Career Development Center (MICDC) is UIC’s TESDA training and assessment center.

For Male students, Gentleman’s cut, presentable and neat. No punky and colored hair, top knot, mohawk, skinhead, one length, mullet, and buzz cut. For Female Students, No excessive make-up, bright or very dark nail polish, and colored streaks on hair

School uniform represents the school. All students shall wear it modestly with respect and dignity befitting students in an Ignacian Marian institution. They come to school, attend classes and other school functions, avail themselves of the school services such as the library, clinic and other facilities in complete uniform. Those who are not wearing the prescribed attire shall not be allowed to enter the campus unless permission is obtained from the OSAD.

On 'wash' days, Saturdays, summer class days and other occasions (e.g., intramural) students are allowed to wear fashion-oriented attire except the following: Grunge “torn” pants, Sleeveless/hanging or tight-fitting, or crop top blouses or t-shirts, Plunging necklines (two inches below the collar bone), backless, Mini-skirts/ shorts / very tight-fitting pants/ leggings, Rubber slippers

A school may suspend, deny, deprive an erring student entry in the school campus or attendance in the classes for a period not exceeding twenty (20%) percent of the prescribed school days for a school year or term. The decision of the school on every case involving the penalty of suspension which exceeds twenty (20%) percent of the prescribed school days for a school year term shall be forwarded to the Commission on Higher Education (CHED)- Regional Office (RO) within ten (10) days from the termination of the investigation of each case for its information. Suspension may include, but not limited to the following: 1. three (3) accumulated warnings for the same offense- on the 4th he/she be meted with suspension. 2. four (4) accumulated warnings for various offenses – he/she be meted with a suspension on the 5th warning. 3) Lending one’s ID to another and the willful possession of two or more ID’s. 4. Extortion, e.g., collecting money from the students in and outside the campus without permission from the duly authorized persons; Using bribery in the form of money, to gain favor from school personnel or faculty. 5. Causing public and campus disturbances, e.g., causing panic or confusion, harassment, throwing of any object in a gathering, disturbing/disrupting authorized practices and performances, symposia, lectures. 6. Publishing or circulating false information or posting malicious remarks in the social network about the University, its officials, personnel, and students 7. Taking part in brawls inside and outside the campus 8. Smoking/ Vaping within the school premises; Smoking/Vaping within 100 meters from the school; Smoking/Vaping in Uniform; Smoking/Vaping while attending any school-related activities. E-Cigarette, Vape Pods, and other smoking paraphernalia will be confiscated 9.  Behavior unbecoming of a UICian, i.e., arrogance, promiscuity, public scandal, and immorality 10. Threatening and/or preventing any student and/or teacher, personnel from entering the school premises or attending classes. 11.Refusing/ failure to appear without valid reason before a school official and/or a duly constituted body when asked to do so 12. Insubordination to authorities. 13. Fraternity and/or Sorority participation: 13.1) Formation or membership in any Fraternity and/or Sorority 13.2) Fraternity and/or initiation 13.3) Participation in terrorist-associated groups or organizations 14. Usurpation (to take or exercise authority or possession wrongfully). 15. Playing/ bringing gambling paraphernalia inside the campus or off-campus school activities 16. Computer security breach: Accessing a University computer or computer network without authority or beyond authorized access. Which includes but are not limited to the following: i. Altering information, (e.g., changing the password of someone else’s account and changing data in files beyond one’s authorized access, etc.) damaging or destroying information (e.g., using someone else’s file, etc.) ii. Making/ introducing false information; iii. Preventing authorized use of information; or iv. Preventing normal operation (e.g., changing the configuration or CMO’s set-up of a PC, introducing computer virus, etc.) of computers or computer networks of the University; v. Hacking/Cracking. vi. Giving of access to school-issued accounts (i.e., Google Classroom, myUIC portal, and Microsoft 365 etc) to unauthorized persons/Piloting accounts vii. Any violation of the Data Privacy Policy of the school. 17. Academic dishonesty in the form of plagiarism, a deliberate, conscious effort of a student to steal another’s original work and pass it off as his/ her own

A school may exclude, drop or dismiss from its rolls a student for a semester, two semesters or both, for a summer, or for the whole school year. A student may be recommended for exclusion which may include but not limited to the following: 1) Pregnancy without the benefit of marriage (for women) and/or impregnating a UICian or non-UICian (for men) 2) Stealing school property that is vital to its operations and valuables of students, teachers, and other school personnel 3) Possessing, accessing, and downloading in the internet pornographic literature 4)Forgery and/or tampering of official school records 5) Securing or using forged and faked school records and terms/ tampering documents/ misrepresentation of facts 6)Assaulting the personnel or student in and outside the campus physically. 7) Giving slanderous/defamatory statements to personnel or students thereby causing injury to his/her person and dishonor inside and outside the campus (verbal, written, or published in any platform) 8)Strikes/demonstration resulting in damage to school properties 9) Instigating or engaging in activities resulting in damage of property vital to school’s operations 10)Doing actions that are contrary to morals inside and outside the campus, especially in uniform. i.e., petting, necking, orgies, sexual acts, and other indecent acts offensive to public laws and Catholic morality 11)Indulging in drugs – using, possessing narcotics and prohibited drugs, such as marijuana, methamphetamine hydrochloride (shabu), prohibited cough syrup or any hallucinogenic agent 12)Misappropriation of funds of student organizations or programs. Any student who fails to account or turn-over funds entrusted to his/her care or custody, without any satisfactory explanation 13)Gambling in any form (digital/physical) inside/ outside the campus (play game for money). 14)Drunkenness and/or possession of liquor, e.g., entering the campus under the influence of liquor of any amount or dosage; bringing liquor inside the campus or any school-related off-campus activities.

The penalty of expulsion is an extreme form of administrative sanction, which debars the student from public and private schools in the Philippines. To be valid and effective, the penalty or expulsion requires the approval of the CHED. Expulsion includes but is not limited to the following: 1. Killing a person within the school campus except for self-defense 2.Hazing, initiation rites, resulting to serious physical injury or death, whether inside or outside the campus 3.Trafficking “mind-altering” drugs within the school campus 4.Injury to the life of any personnel or student (i.e., stabbing, shooting, mauling) 5.Participating in strikes/demonstrations resulting in any injury to life. 6.Hooliganism (e.g., disruptive and unlawful behavior) 7.Immorality or actions resulting in public scandal, e.g., prostitution, adultery, etc. 8.Rape/ attempted rape 9.Sexual harassment 10. Voluntary abortion
